content.description: The route starts easy and quickly involves good footwork - smearing and occasional small edges. Fun moves in the thin, crux section. Eases up after the crux to good holds and good feet.
content.protection: There is a single bolt at the crux. On top there are two good anchors. Walkoff is easy and to climbers left if facing Playhouse Rock. Not what I would consider a beginners route. Can be top roped with draws/slings/cordelette etc...

content.description:
This is the right-leaning crack about 10' right of

Dress Rehearsal

.  Start up an easy slab to reach the crack.  Continue up to the right, passing a vertical section (the crux) about half-way up.  Above this, follow easy slab climbing along a crack, up and left.  Belay from the same spot as for Dress Rehearsal.
content.protection: standard rack, gear belay from the top of the route
content.location: on the right side of Playhouse Rock, left of the tree growing out of the large flake

content.description: 20 feet left of Final Act is this thin shallow crack. Starts from a ledge 20 feet up from the base. Thin crack to sloping ledge with a patina bulge and thin again to the top; most will want to set a TR due to the lack of pro. Zero stars out of five.
content.protection: Small wires or TR with gear

climbs.name: Leading Lady
climbs.fa: Jack Marshall, Dave Wonderly, and A. Avarado, Nov. 1986

content.description: This is a seriously runout face and stemming route up an intermittent crack system.
content.location:
This climb is just to the right of

I'm So Embarrassed For You

.

content.description: The Irritators starts in the crack just to the right of Dress Rehearsal (aka Practice Rehearsal) and proceeds up the brown face to the shared anchor.
Tough slab moves take you to the finish of Stucca By A Yucca.
content.location: Start up two broken slabs just right of Stucca By A Yucca.

climbs.name: I'm So Embarrassed For You
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel and Charles Cole, Feb. 1980

content.description: Start in the middle of Playhouse Rock, on the right side of an obvious bulge that forms a roof low to the ground. The lower section of this climb is the crux and protects well, and is easier than it looks. Although a bit wide, no offwidth technique is required as there is a finger crack within the wide crack, and several nice holds on the face so look around.  After the crux, this route is mostly slab climbing with a crack for pro.  Up high there is one more vertical section with an awesome hand crack that again hits the grade.  Top belay from a gear anchor and walk off to the south.
content.protection: Pro to 4" but can be climbed on a standard rack.
content.location: This crack route goes up the middle of the face

content.description:
This route is the left most line on Playhouse Rock. It follows the obvious crack and corner from the low point in the ground to a point up top near the walk-off. This is shown in the attached photo as being to the

right

of the two lines marked. The protection is available to be safe, but the route is not sewn up. You may also note that I have substantially upgraded the line from 5.4 to 5.6. Although the route is probably mostly 5.4 or easier climbing, I believe that there are a few spots substantially harder and would not advise this as a good beginner lead.

Belay on the top from gear and descend by walking/scrambling to the south (climber's left), down to a gully.

This obscure route climbs the narrow face/arete between

Psycho Groove

and

I'm So Embarrassed For You

and then cuts left at a headwall to join

Curtain Call

(5.6) for it's finish.

The lack of protection in the lower (crux) section will make this a toprope for most. One star out of five.

There is a good photo of this route in Vogel's guide. It goes up some slippery slab to the small arete you can see from the bottom. Then it goes left up to the belay. There are some bolts and chains below where we made a gear anchor-we chose to walk off though.

Incorrectly listed in some guidebooks as "Practice Rehearsal".
content.protection: Some 2' runners are useful as the route turns upward to the right about 50' up.

content.description:
I thought that this climb was a fun climb at the grade. This climb starts up a crack and corner, just right of Final Act. This crack runs out soon, so the climb then heads up a puckered-crack and flakes up diagonally right to another crack above the starting position. This is the left-most of the two twin cracks on the upper half of the crag, the right one being the top end of Psycho Groove.

The climb is quite fun and protects reasonably. Most of the holds are large and secure, particularly up high where the climb gets steeper, but remarkably, easier!

Belay up top using gear, then walk off to the south (climber's left) and scramble down the gully.
content.protection:
A standard rack to 3"

It has been noted that there is a rap anchor just right of the top of this route.

climbs.name: Break a Leg
climbs.fa: Jack Marshall, Dave Wonderly & A. Avarado, November 1986

content.description: Take the slab just right of Final Act to a small roof.

climbs.name: Beck's Bear
climbs.fa: Tom Beck, Tim Ramsey and Curt Shanebeck, November 1978

content.description: Shade in late summer afternoons. Page 132 in Randys guide as are all of Playhouse routes. Easy approach from parking lot right after Lost Horse turn off if going toward Hidden Valley from Jtree. The climb has some pretty good moves in the crux area that make it worth a shot. Many other easy to moderate climbs in the area. Great for beginning leaders or if you simply want to do some easier climbing with a relatively short approach.

climbs.name: Balancing Act
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Brian Prentice, February 1999

content.location: The face just left Final Act

content.description: 30 feet left of Final Act sits this short and sweet little crack. Safe lead for a beginner at Playhouse. Start from a bushy ledge about 30 feet above the base. Would deserve some stars if it were longer. This and the route to the right could have been done before, but they are not in the books. Zero stars out of five.

climbs.name: Anthrax
climbs.fa: Woody Stark , Bill and Karen Briggs

content.description: The left facing dihedral around the corner and to the right of Playwright. I sent it to Bartlett last year and rated it 5.8. He climbed it and felt it was a nine. It was put up by myself, of course, and Bill and Karen Briggs. The ancient ones still are at it.

climbs.name: Stucca By a Yucca
climbs.fa: Rachel Dobrotin and Rick Shull, September 1989

content.description: This route is near the right end of the face.  It goes up one crack system, then traverses right to a second one.  It's not worth doing.
